name: chatgpt_env_marine_gdb_fz
description: [ChatGPT Env] Offshore + GDB FZ â†’ BLOCK (C3 insufficient), suggest RF/SF

turns.content: For the offshore platform project, I see you've selected a GDB-600x600 housing with FZ (C3) material. However, this configuration is blocked.The marine environment introduces several stressors. Salt spray accelerates corrosion of C3-rated materials like galvanized steel. Outdoor condensation can form on the housing's C2-rated surfaces, and high humidity will further accelerate corrosion.The GDB family's bolted construction does not meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for marine environments. Therefore, it's not rated for ENV_MARINE installation (only ENV_INDOOR or ENV_ATEX).Unfortunately, no standard catalog product currently satisfies all requirements simultaneously. A solution would need to be rated for ENV_MARINE installation with a construction type that meets the leakage class and hygiene requirements for this environment, while also providing adequate corrosion resistance for the stressors present.I recommend contacting our Custom Engineering or Technical Support team with these specific technical requirements.To proceed with the configuration, I need two details to address the outdoor condensation risk:

gemini.explanation: The system correctly identifies a critical engineering mismatch between the requested product (GDB with galvanized steel) and the application (offshore platform). It accurately cites the 'indoor use' limitation found in the catalog and applies sound material science reasoning regarding corrosion risks in marine environments.

dimension_explanations.correctness: Correctly identifies that GDB is for 'inomhusbruk' (Indoor use) only (PDF p.8) and that FZ (Galvanized) is unsuitable for marine salt-spray environments.
dimension_explanations.completeness: Fully addresses the user's request by blocking the unsafe configuration, explaining the specific failure modes (corrosion, leakage), and directing the user to custom engineering.
dimension_explanations.safety: Excellent safety logic; prevents a catastrophic failure where galvanized steel would rapidly corrode in an offshore environment.
dimension_explanations.tone: Professional and consultative, explaining the 'why' behind the refusal.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Clear causal chain: Marine environment -> Salt spray/Humidity -> Corrosion of C3/C2 material -> Block.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Strictly adheres to the catalog's 'FÃ¶r inomhusbruk' (For indoor use) constraint for the GDB family.

strengths: Correctly enforces the 'Indoor use only' constraint from PDF p.8
Applies valid HVAC material science (Galvanized steel vs. Marine atmosphere)
Provides a clear path forward (Custom Engineering) rather than just saying no
pdf_citations: Material FZ: 'Korrosivitets klass C3' (PDF p.4) / GDB standard C2 (PDF p.8) - unsuitable for Offshore (C5)

content_segments.text: For the offshore platform project, I see you've selected a GDB-600x600 housing with FZ (C3) material. However, this configuration is blocked.

The marine environment introduces several stressors. Salt spray accelerates corrosion of C3-rated materials like galvanized steel. Outdoor condensation can form on the housing's C2-rated surfaces, and high humidity will further accelerate corrosion.

The GDB family's bolted construction does not meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for marine environments. Therefore, it's not rated for ENV_MARINE installation (only ENV_INDOOR or ENV_ATEX).

Unfortunately, no standard catalog product currently satisfies all requirements simultaneously. A solution would need to be rated for ENV_MARINE installation with a construction type that meets the leakage class and hygiene requirements for this environment, while also providing adequate corrosion resistance for the stressors present.
I recommend contacting our Custom Engineering or Technical Support team with these specific technical requirements.
To proceed with the configuration, I need two details to address the outdoor condensation risk:
